Dear Ms. Gordy:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/13/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the WOC area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of eight foster care files held a late updated medical exam.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at
least every 9 months, unless a greater
frequency is indicated.
Three of eight foster care files did not have a timely, updated dental exam.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(2) For an emergency placement, if any of the
information specified in subrule (1)(a) to (h) of this rule
is not available at the time of placement, then the
agency shall provide information to the foster parent
within 7 calendar days of the placement.

One of eight foster care files did not have the required placement information
documented within seven days of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plan
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
Two of eight foster care files did not have a modified service plan completed
within 30-days of accepting the case.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Five of eight foster care files did not have signed parent agency treatment plans
(PATP) to indicate the parent and foster parent reviewed and received a copy of
the PATP. REPEAT VIOLATION: 6/26/24 interim, CAP approved 8/15/24.
Previously cited as FOM 722-08D.

(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in independent

(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent

(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the required by R
400.12510, continues to reside in a safe and

Two of two IL files did not have monthly budgets completed as required.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
One of three IL files did not have an updated medical or dental completed. The
agency obtained a refusal form. However, it was signed 10-12 months after the
medical and dental examinations were due.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling
and mental health services, and emergency resources.
Two of two IL files did not document the required information was provided to the
youth when the case closed.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination

(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(b) A birth certificate.
Two of two IL files did not document the required information was provided to the
youth when the case closed.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(c) A social security card.
Two of two IL files did not document the required information was provided to the
youth when the case closed.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
Two of two IL files did not document the required information was provided to the
youth when the case closed.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of three adoption home studies was not completed timely.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 209 Orientation and Training- The agency was advised that their
orientation checklist should include training on human trafficking, SOGIE,
trauma informed parenting, and systemic racism. While these trainings are
completed in CWTI, they are required as part of orientation and should be
documented within orientation training.
• Rule 326(1f) Borrowed home- When a borrowed home caregiver completes
orientation with the borrowing agency, the agency documentation must
indicate the date orientation was completed.

• Rule 418 (5) Development of service plans- When parents or foster parents
are unavailable, or unwilling to sign a Parent Agency Treatment Plan, the
agency must document attempts to obtain signatures and the method in
which the plan was provided to the parent or foster parent. Attempts should
continue to be made through visitation and home visits.
• Rule 507(2) Medical, dental and mental health care- For youth that have
refused medical, dental and mental health care, the agency must document
the youth was provided resources for these services. The agency must
provide information on an ongoing basis and encourage the youth to
participate. These efforts must be documented on an ongoing basis. In
addition, as the agency was cited for completing a refusal form 10-12 months
after the due date of an appointment, the agency was reminded that a refusal
form must be completed in a timely manner.
• Rule 502 (2) Program statement and 503(3) Policy and procedures- The
agency was advised to add a signature line to the bottom of their forms, for
the youth's signature to indicate they received a copy of the document.
• Rule 511 (2) Termination- The agency reported that the current DHHS-69
does not include the information required by this rule. The agency was
advised to explore alternatives to document the required information. DCWL
Consultant offered ongoing assistance in this area, to ensure consistency in
this area among agencies.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The agency was reminded to enter case contacts and documents into CWLM
in a timely manner and in the proper section.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The Interim Inspection was completed on 6/26/24 and the CAP was approved on
8/15/24. The agency was cited for twenty-five violations, four of which were
repeats from the 2023 review. During the current review the overall number of
violations decreased to fourteen. Of the fourteen violations, only three were repeat
violations from 2024. It was noted the number of occurrences for each violation
also decreased this year. The agency will need to develop a corrective action plan
to address the new and repeat violations.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001433 was completed on 7/26/24 and the CAP
was approved on 11/1/24. As a result of the investigation, the agency was cited
regarding Rule 400.12310 (3, a). It was determined that during the process of
completing a licensing assessment for a relative caregiver, the child's biological
father was identified as a registered sex offender and used the relative caregiver's
home address as his own. In the home study, the agency did not address this
issue. Although it was determined the father was not living in the relative home, a
violation was found as the agency did not assess the reported sex offender results
in the home study. CAP follow-up occurred on 12/1/24 and 2/7/25. The agency
successfully completed the CAP, and it was closed on 2/24/25. During the current
renewal evaluation, there were no repeat violations found in this area.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001706 was completed on 12/30/24 and the CAP
was approved on 3/19/25. As a result of the investigation, a 1st provisional license
was issued. The agency was cited regarding Rule 400.12507(1) as an IL youth did
not receive sufficient medical attention by staff when she went into labor. The
agency was also cited regarding Rule 400.12503 (2j) as the agency did not have a
specific birth plan developed for the pregnant IL youth. CAP follow-up occurred
with the agency 4/28/25 and 7/21/25. The agency successfully implemented all
CAP action steps, and the CAP was closed on 8/14/25. During the current renewal
evaluation, there were no repeat violations found in this area.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Assessment dated 7/16/25 was reviewed and
discussed. The agency reported several staffing changes since the 2024 review.
However, the CA indicated the team has been able to work together to maintain a
strong structure during these changes.
The CA reported the agency has consistently met their key performance indicators
during this review period. The agency has also effectively implemented the CAPs
from the 2024 interim review and the 7/26/24 and 12/30/24 special investigations.
The CA reported new policies and procedures, increased communication, and
follow-up have helped improve compliance in the areas identified in the CAPs.
The CA reported very few unplanned removals during this review period. One pre-
adoptive placement ended as recommended by the agency and Michigan

Children's Institute, due to the results of an investigation in the home. An IL case
also ended early as the youth no longer qualifying for Youth Adult Voluntary Foster
Care. The agency reported they have worked closely with the local MDHHS
offices to communicate well and prevent unplanned YAVFC moves in the future.
Financial Overview
There were no financial concerns identified based on the review of the agency's
2025 budget and 12/31/23 financial audit. The agency's 2024 financial audit is in
progress.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported they enjoyed their jobs and
did not have concerns or suggestions for improvement at the agency. Both staff
stated their coworkers and supervisors are very kind, supportive, helpful, and work
well together. Staff described administration as being invested and engaging with
staff. The staff reported they enjoy the new office space, although it has been a
change to have everyone together in cubicles, rather than individual offices.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An addendum was completed on 4/2/25 as the agency moved to a new location.
At the 7/21/25 visit the agency was fully occupying the new building. The building
continues to be sufficient for staff and client needs, with meeting and visitation
space. There is a cross shredder for disposal of documents and locking storage
for files and confidential information.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
